vocabulary.example: a dude [n] - a guy or man
pull off (s/t) [phv] - do something difficult successfully (It is surprising that it was successful.)
lifeguarding [v] - working as a lifeguard, a person who protects swimmers at a pool or beach
a country club [n] - a private club for social and recreational activities
lather [v] - apply liquid to something (like hair)
the old mop [n] - slang for hair
natural highlights [n] - lighter strands (pieces) of hair caused by the sun
delicate [adj] - difficult, must be done carefully
play the next 30 seconds right [exp] - make the right decisions for the next 30 seconds
dye [v] - color something like clothes or hair
emphatically [adv] - with emphasis, with feeling, with force
follow my lead [exp] - follow what I do, copy my actions

vocabulary.word: This might be the depression talking.
vocabulary.example: This might be the depression talking. [exp] - This might be because of the depression.

questions.question: Lily thinks Barney looks good with blond hair.
Ted used to be a lifeguard.
Ted used to put lemon juice in his hair.
Ted thinks that he would look good with blond hair.
Robin doesn't want Ted to dye his hair.
Marshall tells Ted that he would look good with blond hair.
They are all disappointed when Ted decides to dye his hair blond.
Only Marshall thinks that Ted looks good with blond hair.
Ted thinks that dying his hair blond was a mistake.

grammar.explanation: Choose the grammatically correct word to complete the sentence, focusing on verb tenses, modals, or negation. Each question has one correct answer and three incorrect options.

exercises.sentence: That summer I ___ lifeguarding at the Chagrin Falls Country Club.
I ___ lathering a little lemon juice into the old mop.
If we play the next 30 seconds right, Ted ___ dye his hair blond.
I ___ know. I'm still kind of full from lunch.
Yes, we ___ all like some nachos.
There is absolutely no way that you ___ pull off blond.
That is not the outcome we ___ hoping for!

transcript.full:
Lily: Say what you will about the guy, but Barney seems right as a blond.

Robin: Well, that's true. Not every dude can pull off that blond look.

Ted: I don't know about that.

Lily: What?

Ted: Oh, that summer I was lifeguarding at the Chagrin Falls Country Club, I was lathering a little lemon juice into the old mop, playing with some natural highlights. Anyway, I'd look good blond.

Marshall: Okay, people, we're in a delicate but very, very promising situation here.

Lily: If we play the next 30 seconds right, Ted will dye his hair blond.

Robin: Guys, this is mean. We can't-- Wup! I just pictured it. How do we do this?

Ted: What are we all thinking about? Nachos?

Marshall: Ted Mosby responds to one thing above all else.

Ted: I don't know. I'm still kind of full from lunch.

Marshall: A bunch of people emphatically telling him not to do something. Follow my lead.

Ted: Ah, screw it, I could eat. Yes, we'd all like some nachos.

Marshall: I love you, buddy, but there's absolutely no way that you could pull off blond.

Robin: It just wouldn't look right.

Lily: Yeah, seriously, Ted, don't go blond.

Ted: I'm going blond!

Lily: No!

Robin: No!

Marshall: That is not the outcome we were hoping for!

Robin: Hey.

Barney: Hey.

Lily: Guys, this might be the depression talking, but is Ted's hair starting to look kind of good?

Marshall: Thank God. I thought I was the only one!

Barney: He looks like a freaking movie star!

Ted: Oh, and by the way, this was a huge mistake. I'm changing my hair back.

Lily: Smart.

Barney: Told you.

Marshall: Not at all awesome.
